newsitem.title: USA: Nu-kote says court invalidates Seiko-Epson patents.
newsitem.headline: Nu-kote says court invalidates Seiko-Epson patents.

text.p: Nu-kote Holdings Inc said Tuesday a federal court had invalidated printer cartridge patents of Japanese printer-maker Seiko Epson, enabling Nu-kote to sell supplies for the printers.

It said the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California had granted a summary judgment in favor of Nu-kote, lifting a preliminary injunction that had prohibited the company from selling supplies for the printers.

It said Judge Terry Hatter ruled on March 5 that Seiko Epson had illegally used the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office to prevent other manufacturers from selling products such as cartridges that were compatible with Seiko Epson printers.

It quoted Ronald Katz, whom it identified as an intellectual property and anti-trust attorney specializing in high technology areas, as saying, "This unprecedented victory is the first court judgment to recognize that Japanese printer manufacturers have systematically been trying to misuse our patent laws to block independent manufacturers from competing in the aftermarket supplies market."
Nu-kote said the after-market business was worth more than $3 billion.
"As prices for printers have dropped dramatically, many manufacturers have focused on the supplies after-market," it said. "These high-margin products provide a reliable source of revenue."
Officials from Seiko-Epson, an affiliate of Seiko Corp, could not be reached for comment.
